title: Gula temple (Kalhu)
description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the goddess Gula. Although its location is not known, the Gula temple at Kalhu is thought to have been part of the Ninurta temple complex (in the northwest corner of the citadel), east of the Šarrat-niphi temple and north of the Kidmuri temple.

properties.description: The proposed, representative location of the Gula temple at Kalhu is based on the suggested position of the building by Julian Reade and the visible remains of the (partially) excavated Šarrat-niphi temple and those of the Northwest palace.
properties.title: Proposed location of the Gula temple
